Shane Mingins wrote:

>  If using TDD you are slowly emerging the design. Why would Extract Class 
> not be a valid refactoring? At some point a private method on a class wants 
> to be a class in it's own. Am I missing something?

If extracting a class causes a method to become public that otherwise 
wouldn't be public, then it's a problem. Public APIs are rigid and 
inflexible. Public APIs can't be easily changed. Private and package 
protected APIs can be. The less you have that's public the more flexible 
your design is.

Now if you genuinely discover that a private method would be more 
broadly useful, and therefore should be public, fine. However if all 
you're doing is splitting up one large unwieldy class into two or more 
smaller classes, then the total number of public methods should not 
change. Most methods that were private in the old class should stay 
private when moved to the new class. perhaps a few will become 
package-protected instead. But they certainly shouldn't change to public 
just because they're moved from class A to class B.
